2022年是迎難而上的一年。

2022年伊始，全球經濟環境一片暗淡。新冠病毒變異株Omicron肆虐，令全球經濟增長繼續受壓，通脹壓力亦持續上升。其後俄羅斯與烏克蘭爆發衝突，進一步推高通脹壓力，導致各主要央行採取前置式貨幣緊縮政策，擴大環球金融市場的波動，並加劇經濟增長放緩的風險。本地方面，第五波疫情爆發，感染個案急速上升，亦進一步打擊經濟。同時，圍繞防疫措施與檢疫限制的負面報道，更令外界對香港產生誤解，威脅香港作為國際金融中心的聲譽。全年計，香港實質本地生產總值收縮了3.5%。

儘管面對重重挑戰，金管局繼續致力保障香港貨幣與金融穩定，並於主要策略範疇推進多項有利發展的措施，進一步鞏固香港的國際金融中心地位。經歷3年的旅遊限制後，我們成功向國際社會展示香港已全面復常，旅客亦能再次親身訪港體驗。金管局在去年11月舉辦「國際金融領袖投資峰會」，來自世界各地的金融領袖親身來港出席。外界如此熱烈的反應，成為印證香港全面復常最好不過的證明。

展望未來，外圍環境仍然充滿前所未有的不確定性。儘管如此，內地經濟重啟會為香港以至整個地區重新注入動力。金管局將繼續緊守崗位，履行維持香港貨幣與銀行體系穩定的職能，並積極尋求更多有利香港發展的機會，展現及提升香港作為國際金融中心的競爭力。我們亦會繼續為提升全球氣候應變能力及可持續發展出力。今年除《二零二二年年報》外，我們會另外發表《二零二二年可持續發展報告》，以便更詳細地介紹金管局在提升香港作為綠色和可持續金融樞紐的地位所進行的各項工作，以及金管局作為負責任投資者及可持續機構所作出的努力。

# 貨幣及金融體系：堅穩如昔

聯繫匯率制度（聯匯制度）自1983年實施至今，歷經多個經濟周期，成功抵禦各種各樣的外來衝擊。2022年再次見證聯匯制度的抗震能力。在美國聯邦儲備局（聯儲局）大幅收緊貨幣政策下，弱方兌換保證於2022年5月至11月期間被觸發41次，金管局按照既定機制，以有序及具透明度的方式從市場買入合共2,421億港元。其間港元匯率及貨幣市場繼續運作暢順，反映聯匯制度穩健有效。

這份對聯匯制度的信心，來自於建立多年的穩固根基。正如國際貨幣基金組織在其《2022年對外部門報告》中重申，聯匯制度的公信力建基於多項因素，包括具高透明度的運作規則、充裕的外匯儲備、審慎的財政制度、穩健的金融監管，以及靈活的經濟結構。

我們深信除了穩健的機制外，致力與公眾及市場溝通以加深其對聯匯制度的了解、進行有效的市場監察，以及就不同情景作出應變計劃，均有助鞏固各界對聯匯制度的信心。我們就聯匯制度運作機制推出的社交媒體宣傳活動，有助在年內弱方兌換保證多次被觸發的情況下，有效維護市場對聯匯制度的信心。內部方面，金管局亦善用數據分析技術加強市場監察，讓我們能適時回應最新市場形勢。

年內，儘管面對宏觀層面的挑戰以及遞增的信用風險，香港銀行體系仍然維持穩健，資本及流動性均非常充裕。2022年底，本地銀行的綜合總資本充足比率為20.1%，遠高於國際最低要求的8%。2022年第4季，大型銀行的流動性覆蓋比率稍升至162.3%，亦遠高於法定最低要求的100%。鑑於信貸環境面對挑戰，銀行體系的資產質素略為轉差，特定分類貸款比率於2022年底升至1.38%，但有關水平仍屬穩健，並低於2000年以來的長期平均水平1.8%。

# 銀行體系：有效監管確保運作穩健

疫情持續3年，來自各方面的挑戰均有所加劇，例如地緣政治緊張局勢升溫及主要央行收緊貨幣政策。然而，全賴多年來妥善的風險管理及有效的監管，香港銀行體系得以維持穩健，繼續發揮支持經濟的重要作用。

過去一年面對的一項主要監管挑戰，是在第五波新冠疫情後經濟仍充滿不確定性之下，確保銀行繼續為客戶提供所需支援的同時，維持穩健的信用風險管理。「預先批核還息不還本」計劃進一步展期，並加入自願性部分本金還款選項，讓借款人可以選擇開始償還部分本金，協助客戶就最終回復正常還款作好準備。

因應主要經濟體大幅收緊貨幣政策令市場波動加劇，2022年金管局另一項主要監管工作是加強監察銀行的市場及流動性風險承擔。我們深入評估各經濟體同步收緊貨幣政策對銀行可能產生的影響，並就壓力測試引入新情景，以評估銀行應對長時間流動性壓力的韌性。

與此同時，我們繼續採取具前瞻性的措施，促進在多個範疇的有效風險管理。在運作穩健性及網絡防衛能力方面，我們提供指引協助銀行制定綜合及全面的運作架構，以達致穩健經營，並就銀行具體的運作範疇提供詳盡監管指引，例如因應雲端技術普及而就使用雲端運算提供指引。此外，因應數碼化加速發展，我們亦加強了應對「網絡釣魚」騙案和推進消費者及投資者保障的工作。

除了維持銀行體系穩健外，金管局亦致力推動普及金融及提高銀行服務的便利性。銀行對於金管局就提供基本銀行服務的呼籲反應正面，有銀行在新發展地區的大型公共屋邨增設分行及自助銀行服務設施。受到疫情相關的旅遊限制影響，許多香港市民無法使用其內地銀行戶口。有見及此，金管局與有關各方緊密合作，協助重新啓動約50萬個內地銀行戶口，受影響戶口持有人無需親身前往內地辦理。

另一個對銀行業持續發展具策略重要性的範疇是提升專業能力。為擴展業務，銀行業對專業人才的需求仍然龐大。金管局在其人才發展策略 — 「連接人才與未來」— 的基礎上，在過去一年推出多項措施，協助銀行業吸引、培育及挽留人才，集中提升及再培訓現有從業員的技能，以及培育年輕一代，以建立可持續的人才庫。

# 國際金融中心：香港重回國際舞台!

實施多時的疫情相關旅遊限制於2022年逐步撤銷，我們作出了多方面的努力讓香港重回國際舞台。11月舉行的「國際金融領袖投資峰會」吸引超過200位來自環球金融機構的國際及地區負責人親臨香港，並獲得全球各地的關注及熱切迴響。儘管峰會舉行日期不巧遇上50年來首個在11月份發出的8號颱風訊號，峰會仍然十分成功，向世界傳遞了香港已全面復常並正展現無比朝氣與活力的有力訊息。我們很高興看到峰會產生了正面的漣漪效應，不少環球金融機構及國際組織現正或計劃在香港舉辦各類活動。

除吸引各地訪客重臨香港外，我和金管局的同事體會到面對面交流聯繫的重要性，因此盡可能親身代表香港出席主要國際會議，積極參與全球政策討論，並藉外訪機會與環球金融機構的集團管理層會面，加深他們對香港穩健的金融體系以及在「一國兩制」下香港提供的各種機遇的了解。

為確保香港保持作為國際金融中心的競爭力，我們在金融科技、內地機遇，以及綠色和可持續金融等策略性重點領域不斷開拓市場新界限。我們亦進一步加強本港的金融平台，提供頂尖的服務，吸引更多企業落戶香港。有關金管局在綠色和可持續金融方面的工作詳情，請參閱《二零二二年可持續發展報告》。

# 金融科技

繼2021年6月公布「金融科技2025」策略，2022年我們在五大範疇均取得顯著進展。

我們在「全面推展銀行數碼化」方面的工作取得理想成果。根據金融科技應用評估的結果，香港銀行業在不同業務領域廣泛採用金融科技，而且所採用的科技類別亦持續增加。我們自2017年以來逐步推廣及支持數碼化的工作獲銀行積極回應，並持續取得成果，成續令人鼓舞。我們將繼續與業界緊密合作，根據評估的結果，進一步推動金融科技在特定銀行業務領域的應用及促進個別科技類別的發展。

年內我們在央行數碼貨幣方面的工作邁進重要的新里程。「多種央行數碼貨幣跨境網絡」(mBridge)項目進入試行階段，並成為全球其中一個率先為企業跨境交易進行真實結算的央行數碼貨幣項目。在零售層面，數字人民幣跨境使用的技術測試已進入第二階段，主要測試通過「轉數快」為數字人民幣錢包增值。數碼港元方面，我們將採取三軌道方式為將來可能發行數碼港元作好準備，並推出第二軌道先導計劃，邀請業界深入研究數碼港元可行的應用場景。

數據可全面釋放金融科技的潛力。我們於去年10月推出的「商業數據通」正是提升香港數據基建的重要一步。作為以數據擁有人授權為本的共享數據基建，「商業數據通」能方便金融機構提取企業的商業數據，使企業（尤其中小型企業）更容易獲得融資。截至2022年底，「商業數據通」已促成超過1,000宗中小企貸款，總額逾19億港元。

最後，我們在擁抱金融創新和它帶來的好處的同時，亦明白有必要監察及處理好相關發展可能帶來的風險。我們正密切注視虛擬資產領域的發展，並參與相關監管事宜的國際討論。經考慮公眾諮詢收集到的意見及相關國際標準後，我們將採納「相同風險，相同監管」1 的方式制定穩定幣的監管制度及界定其監管範圍。未來我們率先規管的對象將是那些標榜與一種或以上法定貨幣的價值掛鈎的穩定幣，因為這類穩定幣可能對貨幣及金融穩定帶來更高及更迫切的潛在風險。我們相信在訂立適當的規範下，業界將可更安全穩妥地開拓數碼金融的潛力。

科技正重塑我們的未來。金管局與銀行業界正積極準備迎向這個「新常態」。我們有信心我們正構建的金融科技生態圈將有助全面釋放金融科技的潛力，並提升香港作為國際金融中心的競爭力。

# 內地機遇
en:
2022 was a year of facing challenges head-on.

At the start of 2022, the global economic environment was bleak. The Omicron variant of the coronavirus raged, continuing to put pressure on global economic growth and driving inflation upwards. Subsequently, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine further intensified inflationary pressures, prompting major central banks to adopt proactive monetary tightening policies, expanding volatility in global financial markets and exacerbating the risk of slowing economic growth. Locally, a fifth wave of the pandemic erupted, causing a rapid increase in infections and further impacting the economy. Simultaneously, negative reports surrounding防疫 measures and quarantine restrictions created a misunderstanding of Hong Kong abroad, threatening Hong Kong's reputation as an international financial center. For the entire year, Hong Kong's real gross domestic product contracted by 3.5%.

Despite facing numerous challenges, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority remains committed to safeguarding Hong Kong’s monetary and financial stability, and has implemented several beneficial measures across key strategic areas to further solidify Hong Kong’s position as an international financial center. Following three years of travel restrictions, we have successfully demonstrated to the international community that Hong Kong has fully returned to normal, and visitors can once again experience the city firsthand. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority hosted the “International Financial Leaders Investment Summit” in November last year, which was attended in person by financial leaders from around the world. This enthusiastic response from the international community is the best testament to Hong Kong’s full recovery.

Looking ahead, the external environment remains fraught with unprecedented uncertainty. Nevertheless, the mainland China's economic recovery will inject fresh momentum into Hong Kong and the broader region. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority will continue to steadfastly fulfill its role in maintaining the stability of Hong Kong's monetary and banking systems, and actively seek opportunities to promote Hong Kong’s development and enhance its competitiveness as an international financial center. We will also continue to contribute to enhancing global climate resilience and sustainable development. In addition to the 2022 Annual Report, we will publish a separate 2022 Sustainability Report to provide a more detailed account of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s efforts in bolstering Hong Kong’s position as a green and sustainable finance hub, as well as our endeavors as a responsible investor and sustainable organization.

# Monetary and Financial Systems: As Solid as Ever

The linked exchange rate system (managed float) has been in operation since 1983 and has withstood numerous economic cycles and a wide range of external shocks. In 2022, it once again demonstrated its resilience. Under the significant tightening of monetary policy by the U.S. Federal Reserve, the guaranteed exchange rate band was triggered 41 times between May and November 2022. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority, in accordance with established mechanisms, purchased a total of HKD 242.1 billion from the market in an orderly and transparent manner. Throughout this period, the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate and money market continued to function smoothly, reflecting the stability and effectiveness of the linked exchange rate system.

This confidence in the linked exchange rate system stems from a solid foundation built over many years. As the International Monetary Fund reaffirmed in its "Report on External Reserves 2022," the credibility of the linked exchange rate system is based on several factors, including transparent operating rules, ample foreign exchange reserves, prudent fiscal policies, sound financial regulation, and a flexible economic structure.

We firmly believe that, in addition to robust mechanisms, actively communicating with the public and the market to deepen their understanding of the linked exchange rate system, conducting effective market surveillance, and developing contingency plans for different scenarios will all help consolidate confidence in the system across various sectors. Our social media promotional campaign introducing the linked exchange rate system’s operational mechanisms has helped effectively maintain market confidence in the system despite the linked exchange rate assurance being triggered multiple times this year. Internally, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority also utilizes data analysis technology to strengthen market surveillance, allowing us to respond promptly to the latest market developments.

Within the year, despite facing macroeconomic challenges and increasing credit risks, Hong Kong's banking system remained robust, with ample capital and liquidity. As of the end of 2022, local banks' combined capital adequacy ratio was 20.1%, well above the international minimum requirement of 8%. In the fourth quarter of 2022, the liquidity coverage ratio of large banks rose slightly to 162.3%, also significantly exceeding the statutory minimum requirement of 100%. Given the challenges facing the credit environment, the asset quality of the banking system deteriorated slightly, with the specific non-performing loan ratio rising to 1.38% at the end of 2022, but this level remains sound and below the long-term average of 1.8% since 2000.

# Banking System: Effective Regulation Ensures Stable Operation

The pandemic has continued for three years, and challenges from all quarters have intensified, such as escalating geopolitical tensions and tightening monetary policies by major central banks. However, thanks to sound risk management and effective regulation over the years, Hong Kong's banking system has remained robust and continues to play a vital role in supporting the economy.

A major regulatory challenge over the past year has been ensuring that banks continue to provide the support their customers need while maintaining sound credit risk management, all against a backdrop of ongoing economic uncertainty following the fifth wave of the COVID-19 pandemic. The "advance approval of interest payment without principal repayment" program has been extended, and a voluntary partial principal repayment option has been added, allowing borrowers to choose to begin repaying a portion of the principal and helping customers prepare for a return to normal repayment schedules.

In response to increased market volatility stemming from significant tightening of monetary policies by major economies, a key regulatory focus for the Financial Supervisory Authority in 2022 has been strengthening the monitoring of banks’ market and liquidity risk exposures. We have conducted an in-depth assessment of the potential impact of synchronized monetary tightening across various economies on banks, and have introduced new scenarios in stress testing to evaluate banks’ resilience to prolonged liquidity pressures.

At the same time, we continue to implement proactive measures to promote effective risk management across various areas. In terms of operational resilience and cybersecurity capabilities, we provide guidance to banks in developing comprehensive and robust operational frameworks to ensure stable operations, and offer detailed regulatory guidance tailored to specific operational areas of banks, such as providing guidance on the use of cloud computing in response to the widespread adoption of cloud technology. Furthermore, in response to the accelerated development of digitalization, we have strengthened our efforts to combat “phishing” scams and promote consumer and investor protection.

Besides maintaining the stability of the banking system, the Financial Services and Treasury Bureau is also committed to promoting financial inclusion and enhancing the convenience of banking services. Banks have responded positively to the Bureau's call for providing basic banking services, with some establishing branches and self-service banking facilities in large public housing estates in newly developed areas. Due to travel restrictions related to the pandemic, many Hong Kong citizens have been unable to use their mainland bank accounts. Recognizing this, the Bureau has worked closely with relevant parties to reactivate approximately 500,000 mainland bank accounts, allowing affected account holders to avoid traveling to mainland China to complete the process.

Another area of strategic importance for the continued development of the banking sector is enhancing professional capabilities. The industry’s demand for skilled professionals remains substantial as it seeks to expand its operations. Building on its talent development strategy – “Connecting Talent with the Future” – the Financial Supervisory Commission has launched several measures over the past year to help the banking sector attract, nurture, and retain talent, focusing on upskilling and reskilling existing employees, as well as cultivating the next generation to build a sustainable talent pool.

# International Finance Centre: Hong Kong Returns to the Global Stage!

After gradually lifting the COVID-related travel restrictions implemented for a long time in 2022, we have made extensive efforts to bring Hong Kong back to the international stage. The "Global Financial Leaders Investment Summit" held in November attracted over 200 senior executives from global financial institutions, both international and regional, to Hong Kong, garnering widespread attention and enthusiastic responses worldwide. Despite the unfortunate timing coinciding with the first No. 8 typhoon signal issued in November in 50 years, the summit was a resounding success, effectively conveying to the world that Hong Kong has fully returned to normal and is demonstrating remarkable vitality and dynamism. We are pleased to see the summit has generated positive ripple effects, with numerous global financial institutions and international organizations currently hosting or planning to host various events in Hong Kong.

Beyond attracting visitors to return to Hong Kong, my colleagues at the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and I have realized the importance of face-to-face communication and connection. Therefore, I strive to represent Hong Kong in person at major international conferences, actively participate in global policy discussions, and use overseas trips as opportunities to meet with the management teams of global financial institutions to deepen their understanding of Hong Kong’s robust financial system and the various opportunities offered under the “One Country, Two Systems” framework.

To ensure Hong Kong maintains its competitiveness as an international financial center, we are continuously exploring new markets in strategic focus areas such as financial technology, opportunities in the Mainland, and green and sustainable finance. We are also further strengthening Hong Kong’s financial platforms to provide top-tier services and attract more businesses to establish themselves here. For details on the Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s work in green and sustainable finance, please refer to the “Sustainable Development Report 2022.”

# Financial technology

Following the release of the "FinTech 2025" strategy in June 2021, we have made significant progress in all five key areas in 2022.

Our work in promoting the comprehensive digitalization of banking has yielded excellent results. According to the assessment of fintech applications, the banking sector in Hong Kong has widely adopted fintech across various business areas, and the categories of technology utilized continue to expand. Our phased promotion and support of digitalization since 2017 have been met with positive responses from banks and have consistently produced encouraging results. We will continue to work closely with the industry, and based on the assessment findings, further promote the application of fintech in specific banking business areas and foster the development of individual technology categories.

Within the year, our work on central bank digital currency has reached a significant new milestone. The "Multiple Central Bank Digital Currency (CBDC) Cross-Border Network" (mBridge) project has entered a pilot phase and become one of the world’s leading central bank digital currency projects to conduct real-world settlements for cross-border corporate transactions. On the retail front, technical testing for the cross-border use of the digital RMB has entered its second phase, primarily testing the top-up of digital RMB wallets through Faster Payment System. Regarding digital Hong Kong dollars, we will adopt a three-track approach to prepare for the potential future issuance of digital Hong Kong dollars and will launch a pilot program for the second track, inviting industry players to explore viable application scenarios for digital Hong Kong dollars.

Data can fully unlock the potential of financial technology. Our “Business Data Interchange,” launched in October last year, is an important step in enhancing Hong Kong’s data infrastructure. As a shared data infrastructure based on data owner authorization, “Business Data Interchange” facilitates financial institutions in extracting business data from companies, making it easier for businesses (particularly small and medium-sized enterprises) to obtain financing. As of the end of 2022, “Business Data Interchange” has facilitated over 1,000 SME loans, with a total value exceeding HKD 1.9 billion.

While embracing financial innovation and its benefits, we also recognize the need to monitor and address the risks associated with its development. We are closely watching the evolution of the virtual asset space and participating in international discussions on related regulatory matters. After considering the feedback received from public consultation and relevant international standards, we will adopt a “same risk, same regulation” approach to formulate a regulatory regime for stablecoins and define its scope. Our initial focus will be on stablecoins that claim to be pegged to one or more fiat currencies, as these pose potentially higher and more immediate risks to monetary and financial stability. We believe that, with appropriate regulations in place, the industry will be able to more safely and securely unlock the potential of digital finance.

在加強香港金融平台的競爭力方面取得良好進展，涵蓋債券發行、資產及財富管理、企業財資中心，以及綠色和可持續金融等範疇。

# 2022 Year in Review

# Economic and Financial Environment

Affected by multiple unfavorable factors including the fifth wave of the COVID-19 pandemic, tightening financial conditions, and a challenging external environment, Hong Kong's economy contracted significantly in 2022. The labor market initially deteriorated before gradually improving, while inflation remained moderate. Benefiting from the full resumption of travel between mainland China and Hong Kong, Hong Kong's economy is expected to recover from a low base in 2023.

Hong Kong's banking system remained robust in 2022, with ample capital and liquidity, and continued to maintain a healthy asset quality.

# Currency Stability

As the United States tightens its monetary policy, the Hong Kong dollar has weakened, triggering the linked exchange rate assurance scheme multiple times this year. However, Hong Kong's foreign exchange and money markets have continued to operate in an orderly and smooth manner, repeatedly demonstrating the stability and effectiveness of the linked exchange rate system.

# Inventory Management

The investment environment in 2022 was exceptionally volatile, with prices across various asset classes declining simultaneously. The foreign exchange fund recorded an overall investment return of negative 4.5%, a relatively mild loss compared to the performance of most multi-asset funds in the market.

The Financial Services and Markets Authority continues to promote responsible investing and asset diversification. Meanwhile, the internal rate of return of the Long-Term Growth Portfolio has been 12.6% annually since its investments began in 2009.

# Banking system stability

Faced with increasing volatility in financial markets, the Financial Supervisory Commission is strengthening its oversight of banks' credit and market risk management, and working closely with banks to enhance their operational resilience and cybersecurity capabilities, in response to the continued rise in cyber threats and the accelerated pace of digital transformation in the banking sector.

The Financial Services and Markets Authority has further introduced consumer protection measures regarding "buy now, pay later" products and arrangements for refinancing mortgages. In addition, the Authority has collaborated with other regulatory bodies to develop a regulatory framework for virtual assets, issued guidance on the distribution of investment products, and launched a new trust business regulatory system. A "credit data platform" under the "multiple credit data service providers" model for personal credit data was also activated within the year.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) continues to collaborate with banks to enhance Hong Kong’s anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing (AML/CTF) ecosystem, strengthen measures to respond to fraud, and further promote the application of data and technology through the “AML Regulatory Technology (RegTech) Lab” series, as well as accelerate the HKMA’s adoption of regulatory technology in its AML work.

The Monetary Authority has made good progress in implementing international regulatory standards, such as capital adequacy and disclosure standards, locally. It is also working with the banking sector to build a sustainable talent pool and enhance employee skills for future development.

To ensure Hong Kong has credible resolution mechanisms, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority has established new resolution standards, conducted regional crisis simulation exercises, and established a new layer of loss-absorbing capacity resources at all banks of local systemic importance, marking an important milestone in the development of resolution mechanisms.

# Hong Kong's Status as an International Financial Centre

The International Financial Leaders Investment Summit was a success, solidifying Hong Kong's position as a global financial hub and generating positive ripple effects.

The currency swap agreement between the People's Bank of China and the Hong Kong Monetary Authority has been optimized this year, further solidifying Hong Kong's position as a global hub for offshore Renminbi business. The Monetary Authority is also working with other regulatory bodies and stakeholders to prepare for the launch of "Cross-Border Interbank Payment System" (CIPS) and to introduce a dual-counter model for market makers facilitating the trading of Renminbi-denominated stocks in Hong Kong. Furthermore, it is committed to developing the central clearing system for debt instruments into a leading international central securities depository platform for the Asian region.

Significant progress has been made in strengthening the competitiveness of Hong Kong's financial platform, covering areas such as bond issuance, asset and wealth management, corporate treasury centers, and green and sustainable finance.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority continues to implement the "FinTech 2025" strategy, promoting the adoption of financial technology within the financial sector and enhancing Hong Kong's position as a fintech hub. The Fast Payment System "Faster Payment System" (FPS) has seen steady growth in usage as its functionalities are enhanced.

# Organizational Functions

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority maintains effective communication with the public and the market through various channels to enhance understanding of its policies and work.

Internally, the Financial Supervisory Commission has diligently built a work team that emphasizes adaptability and sustainable development, while adhering to strict financial discipline and enhancing information technology capabilities, to respond to changes and ensure the effective implementation of various policies and measures.

# 2月14日

金融學院轄下負責研究工作的香港貨幣及金融研究中心發表新一份題為《人口轉變及長期資產市場：香港的機遇及發展》的應用金融研究報告（英文版）。

# 3月8日

國際貨幣基金組織（基金組織）代表團就香港特別行政區2022年第四條磋商發表評估報告，再次肯定香港作為主要國際金融中心的地位，具備穩健強韌的金融體系、有效的宏觀經濟及審慎政策，以及健全的規管及監管框架，並認同香港金融業在疫情期間，依然持續擴張和發展。

基金組織亦讚揚香港在應對氣候變化方面取得重大進展，並認同政府努力不懈加強綠色和可持續金融生態圈。

# 3月30日

綠色和可持續金融跨機構督導小組公布對香港碳市場機遇的初步可行性評估。根據評估結果，督導小組公布支持香港發展成為區域碳交易中心的後續工作。

# 4月12日

香港貨幣及金融研究中心與金融學院合辦「宏觀經濟最新發展、美聯儲收緊貨幣政策及離岸人民幣市場的發展」線上研討會，吸引84萬人次在線參與。

# 4月27日

金管局發布題為《從政策及設計角度看「數碼港元」》的討論文件，闡述在香港引入零售層面央行數碼貨幣（即「數碼港元」或e-HKD）所涉及的主要政策及設計事項，並徵求意見。

# 5月3日

金管局和世界銀行集團成員國際金融公司共同發起的「綠色商業銀行聯盟」與渣打銀行於網上合辦「綠色及可持續資本市場蛻變圓桌會議」。

# Chronicle of Major Events in 2022

# Currency Stability

# May 26th

The government issued HK$500 million in 20-year Hong Kong dollar government bonds through a tender process under its "Institutional Bond Issuance Program."

# July 4th

The People's Bank of China (PBOC) and the Hong Kong Monetary Authority have announced an optimization of the currency swap agreement, changing it to a standing agreement that no longer requires renewal. The agreement's size has been expanded from 500 billion yuan/590 billion Hong Kong dollars to 800 billion yuan/940 billion Hong Kong dollars.

# July 13th

The Financial Supervisory Commission has issued an updated commitment statement regarding the "Global Foreign Exchange Market Principles," reaffirming its commitment to adhere to the updated version of the principles when operating in the foreign exchange market as a market participant.

# July 22nd

The Financial Supervisory Agency announced optimized arrangements for RMB liquidity funding, including expanded scale and simplified procedures.

# Banking system

# January 28

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) have jointly issued a circular providing updated guidance to intermediaries engaging in virtual asset-related activities to protect clients.

# January 28

The Financial Supervisory Agency has updated its regulatory guidelines regarding the supervision of banks and virtual asset service providers in relation to money laundering and terrorist financing risks associated with virtual assets.

# February 8th

The Financial Services and Markets Commission has announced an extension of the "Banking Sector Talent Launch Program" by six months.

# February 23

Hong Kong Mortgage Corporation Limited (Mortgage Corporation) announces amendments and an expansion of the scope of its mortgage insurance scheme for completed residential properties, made by its wholly-owned subsidiary, Hong Kong Mortgage Insurance Company Limited (Mortgage Insurance Company).

# February 23

The "100% Guaranteed Personal Concessionary Loan Scheme" has introduced enhanced measures (effective April 19) and extended the application period to the end of April 2023.

# February 23

The Financial Services and Markets Commission, in conjunction with the Coordination Mechanism for SME Loans in the Banking Sector, has announced an extension of the "Pre-Approved Principal and Interest Payment Only" scheme for six months until the end of October. The repayment period for trade financing loan principal can be extended by 90 days. The scheme also provides a one-year partial principal repayment option, allowing borrowers who are willing and able to gradually return to normal repayment schedules.

The SME Financing Guarantee Scheme has also launched enhanced measures (effective April 1st) and extended the application period to June 30, 2023.

# April 1st

The Financial Supervisory Commission and the Insurance Supervisory Administration have introduced measures to strengthen customer protection regarding the purchase of whole life insurance policies through premium financing.

# April 14th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has issued guidance to Hong Kong banks regarding assisting Hong Kong citizens in reactivating their mainland bank accounts under the quarantine restrictions implemented due to the epidemic.

# April 26th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has launched a “RegTech Information Platform” to encourage the exchange of experience and specialized knowledge within Hong Kong’s RegTech ecosystem regarding the application of RegTech.

# April 28th

The Financial Supervisory Authority has announced a joint launch of the "Banking Industry Graduate Training Program" with the banking sector to expand the talent pool for the industry's rapidly growing areas.

# May 5th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has approved a “mandatory background check scheme” to be implemented by the Hong Kong Association of Banks (HKAB) and the Association of Deposit-Taking Companies, aimed at addressing the issue of “rolling bad apples” within the Hong Kong banking sector.

# May 6th

The "100% Guaranteed Individual Concessionary Loan Scheme" is now accepting applications from individual landlords affected by the temporary suspension of rent recovery arrangements, until October 31st.

# May 25th

The Financial Services and Markets Authority has released a report (in English) on a thematic evaluation of incentive schemes for frontline staff in retail banking, to continuously promote a sound banking culture.

# May 27th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has issued the "Trust Business Operation Guidelines" and a new section of the "Regulatory Policy Handbook" to strengthen the regulation and supervision of trust businesses in Hong Kong.

# May 31st

The wholly-owned Hong Kong Annuity Limited, a subsidiary of a mortgage securities company, has announced enhancements and promotional offers for its Hong Kong annuity plan. The enhancements include an increased limit on the amount that can be withdrawn for "medical and dental expenses" and an increased limit on the total personal premium amount.

# June 23rd

The Financial Supervisory Agency has released the results of its assessment of fintech applications and a related work plan to further support the industry’s adoption of fintech.

# July 1st

The Banking (Capital) (Amendment) Rules 2022, formulated to implement the Basel Committee’s “Capital Requirements for Banks’ Equity Investments in Funds,” have come into effect.

# July 6th to 8th

The Financial Supervisory Commission participated in the design and execution of a three-day regional crisis simulation exercise. The exercise involved ten central banks, regulatory and resolution authorities, and deposit insurance institutions from the Asia-Pacific region, aiming to strengthen cross-border cooperation.

# July 8th

The Financial Supervisory Agency has issued guidance on the sale of linked insurance policies with guaranteed returns by licensed institutions, to protect consumers.

# July 8th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has issued guidance to banks and licensed stored value facilities operators based on the key findings and relevant implications outlined in the government’s “Hong Kong Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing Risk Assessment Report 2022.”

# July 20

The Financial Services and Markets Commission welcomes the Banking Association’s announcement of an additional payment arrangement for customers regarding mortgage refinancing transactions. Participating banks will begin offering this new property transaction payment arrangement starting November 7th.

# July 21st

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority and Cyberport, with assistance from Deloitte, jointly hosted the second "Anti-Money Laundering Regulatory Technology (RegTech) Laboratory (AMLab 2), primarily focusing on "easy-to-use technology" that is low-threshold and readily implementable.

# September 2nd

The Financial Services and Markets Authority has introduced a series of consumer protection measures for banks’ “buy now, pay later” products to promote responsible lending.

# September 8th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has announced the launch of a one-stop online resource platform called "Banking Navigator" and the second cohort of the "Banking Bridging Course."

# September 16

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority, together with the Coordination Mechanism for SME Financing by Banks, has announced an extension of the "Pre-approved Principal Repayment Deferral" scheme for three months until the end of January 2023.

On the same day, Assurance Company announced that the principal and interest repayment deferral arrangement under the SME Financing Guarantee Scheme will also be extended, allowing borrowing enterprises to apply for a maximum deferral of 36 months for principal repayment.

# September 26

The Financial Services and Markets Commission has finalized the implementation details of the "Fintech Employee Training Subsidy Pilot Program" and formally launched the program within the banking sector.

# September 27

The Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) and the Insurance Authority (IA) have released the results of their second annual joint survey on the sale of non-exchange traded investment products by licensed corporations and registered institutions. A total of 327 licensed corporations and 63 registered institutions reported data on their sales of investment products in 2021, with total transaction volume reaching HK$50,150 billion. The number of participating investors increased by 5% to 770,000.

# September 27

The Financial Supervisory Commission has launched a "Compliance" module under the "Banking Professional Qualification Framework," collaborating with the banking industry to develop a set of competency standards that can be jointly adopted and are transparent, aiming to enhance the professional capabilities of employees engaged in compliance work.

# October 6th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority, in collaboration with the Hong Kong Association of Banks, banks, and the stored-value facilities payment tool industry, is supporting the Hong Kong Police Force in launching the “Anti-Deception Trap Detector” to strengthen the prevention, detection, and suppression of fraudulent activities in society and reduce public financial losses.

In addition to issuing practical guidelines and updating relevant FAQs, the Financial Services and Markets Authority has also collaborated with banks and the stored-value facilities industry to raise public awareness of fraud prevention through consumer education materials on websites and social media, and has published articles in "Money Insight" to explain this work.

# October 20th

The Financial Services and Markets Commission, together with the "Coordination Mechanism for SME Loans in the Banking Sector," has announced an extension of the "Pre-approved Principal and Interest Repayment Deferral" scheme for six months until the end of July 2023. It has also optimized some principal repayment options to assist capable businesses in gradually returning to normal repayment schedules.

According to the insurance company, the application period for the "SME Financing Guarantee Scheme" allowing repayment of interest but not principal has been extended by six months to the end of June 2023, and the maximum repayment period has also been extended by six months to a total of up to 42 months.

# October 21st

The Financial Supervisory Agency has issued two circulars to update the requirements for selling and distributing loss-compensating products and to provide guidance on suitability assessments.

# November 24th

The Financial Services and Markets Authority (FMA) is partnering with Cyberport, with assistance from Deloitte, to host the third “Anti-Money Laundering Compliance Technology Lab (AMLab 3).” AMLab 3 builds upon the achievements of previous AMLab series, utilizing network analysis to address fraud risks and mitigate losses caused by networks of shell accounts.

# November 28th

With the strong support of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, a “credit data platform” operating under a “multiple credit data service agency” model has commenced operations, aiming to enhance the service quality of Hong Kong’s personal credit data service agencies and mitigate operational risks arising from the current situation where only one commercial operator provides the service.

# December 7th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has issued a circular to banks regarding the draft "Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorist Financing Ordinance (Revised) 2022," which will take effect in June 2023, clarifying the latest amendments relevant to the banking sector.

# December 15th

The Financial Supervisory Agency is hosting a seminar for banks and the stored-value payment instrument industry on combating money laundering and the financing of terrorism (AML). The seminar will cover updates to regulatory requirements, AML regulatory and compliance technology, regulatory requirements for source of wealth, feedback on suspicious transaction reporting, and updates on mitigating the risk of financing the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction.

# December 23rd

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority, the Insurance Authority, and the Mandatory Provident Fund Schemes Authority have jointly issued a circular outlining the key findings and good practices observed from their first joint mystery shopping exercise concerning the sales practices of two tax-deductible products (namely, qualifying deferred annuity policies and tax-deductible voluntary contributions to the Mandatory Provident Fund) by three intermediaries.

# December 31st

All Hong Kong banks deemed systemically important have established a new layer of financial resources to absorb losses during resolution, marking a milestone for the Hong Kong Monetary Authority in enhancing the resolvability of these banks and the resilience of the banking system.

# Hong Kong's Status as an International Financial Centre

# January 12th

The Financial Services and Markets Authority has released a discussion paper on digital assets and stablecoins, outlining its initial thoughts on a regulatory framework for digital assets, particularly stablecoins used for payment purposes, and inviting feedback from the industry and the public on the proposed framework.

# January 27

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Swiss Federal International Financial Secretariat, under the Swiss Federal Department of Finance, jointly hosted the fifth Hong Kong-Switzerland Financial Cooperation Dialogue online.

# February

The Financial Services and Markets Authority has been re-appointed as co-chair of the Evaluation and Compliance Group under the Financial Action Task Force for a two-year term. The Financial Action Task Force is a global standard-setting body for combating money laundering.

# February 11th

The mortgage securities company announced that it has signed a memorandum of understanding with 14 partner banks to establish a framework for infrastructure loan cooperation, outlining the main principles for collaboration on infrastructure loans.

# February 14th

The Hong Kong Monetary and Financial Research Centre, under the Faculty of Business, has released a new applied financial research report (in English) titled "Demographic Shifts and Long-Term Asset Markets: Opportunities and Development for Hong Kong."

# March 8th

The International Monetary Fund (IMF) delegation has released an evaluation report following its Article IV consultation on Hong Kong Special Administrative Region for 2022, reaffirming Hong Kong’s position as a leading international financial center. The report highlights Hong Kong’s robust and resilient financial system, effective macroeconomic and prudent policies, and a sound regulatory and supervisory framework, and acknowledges the continued expansion and development of Hong Kong’s financial sector during the pandemic.

The organization also praised Hong Kong's significant progress in addressing climate change and recognized the government's persistent efforts to strengthen the green and sustainable finance ecosystem.

# March 30th

The Green and Sustainable Finance Cross-Agency Task Force has released a preliminary feasibility assessment of opportunities in Hong Kong's carbon market. Based on the assessment results, the Task Force has announced follow-up work to support Hong Kong's development as a regional carbon trading hub.

# April 12th

The Hong Kong Monetary and Financial Research Centre and the Business School co-hosted an online seminar on "Recent Developments in Macroeconomics, the Federal Reserve's Tightening of Monetary Policy, and the Development of the Offshore Renminbi Market," attracting over 840,000 online participants.

# April 27

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has released a discussion paper titled "Digital Hong Kong Dollar: Policy and Design Considerations," outlining the key policy and design considerations involved in introducing a central bank digital currency (referred to as the "Digital Hong Kong Dollar" or e-HKD) for retail use in Hong Kong, and soliciting feedback.

# May 3rd

The Green Banking Alliance, launched jointly by the Financial Supervisory Commission and the International Finance Corporation, a member of the World Bank Group, and Standard Chartered Bank co-hosted an online roundtable discussion on "Transforming Green and Sustainable Capital Markets."

# 2023年工作重點及前瞻

儘管香港經濟在2023 年初出現復甦跡象，但外圍環境仍然充滿挑戰及不確定性。近期美國和歐洲的銀行業受壓，個別美國本土銀行在2023 年3 月倒閉，對環球金融市場造成漣漪效應，而主要央行收緊貨幣政策，很有可能令2023 年全球經濟增長放緩甚或衰退。另一方面，地緣政治局勢緊張，以及去全球化的威脅持續，可能會繼續拖累全球貿易，並會令環球金融市場不時出現波動。儘管如此，香港金融體系憑藉多年來所建立穩健的抗震能力及充裕的緩衝，有足夠能力抵禦不利衝擊。

金管局非常重視保障貨幣及金融穩定。展望未來，面對不明朗的宏觀經濟環境，金管局會保持警惕，力求迅速辨識正浮現的風險，並靈活應對。與此同時，金管局會繼續把握機遇及創造政策空間，進一步提升香港作為主要國際金融中心的地位。面對充滿挑戰的投資環境，金管局在管理外匯基金時會繼續審慎投資，同時保持足夠靈活性，按需要採取防禦措施，並維持高流動性。

# 金融體系保持穩定健全

環球經濟前景仍受制於重大的不確定因素。金管局會密切注視最新發展，提高警覺，防範各種潛在風險，以維持金融體系穩定健全；這是關乎持續提供關鍵金融服務的先決條件，因此亦是維繫香港經濟正常運作的命脈。

# 對潛在風險保持警惕

在2023年，美國利率未來走勢的不確定性，以及在先進經濟體銀行體系出現的壓力，可能會對主要先進經濟體的增長前景帶來下行風險。此外，持續的地緣政治風險，可能會繼續拖累全球貿易，並會令環球金融市場不時出現波動。然而，香港金融體系憑藉過去多年所建立的抗震能力及緩衝，有足夠能力抵禦不利衝擊。金管局亦有能力、資源及決心維持香港貨幣及金融穩定。

金管局將繼續密切注視本地及外圍環境的風險與脆弱性，並會按需要採取適當措施維持香港的貨幣及金融體系穩定。金管局亦會研究對香港經濟有影響的事項，以及評估與這些事項相關的潛在風險。

# 保持銀行體系穩定

鑑於地緣政治緊張局勢升級，以及各主要央行大幅加息以遏抑通脹，預計2023年銀行業的經營環境仍然充滿挑戰。另一方面，科技發展迅速及數碼化對銀行業來說既有危又有機。面對瞬息萬變的金融環境，金管局致力透過持續的監管工作確保銀行具足夠能力抵禦衝擊。與此同時，金管局亦會參照國際標準及最佳做法，繼續加強及優化銀行監管架構與政策。

# 風險為本的監管重點

# 信用、流動性及市場風險

在2023年，金管局將繼續密切注視認可機構的資產質素，並聚焦於認可機構的貸款分類及撥備做法，以及對財務狀況較差的借款人的管理。金管局亦會加強其監察系統，並採取積極措施確保銀行體系的整體信用風險水平維持可控。

另一方面，金管局會繼續留意企業的營運環境，並與銀行業及商界保持緊密溝通，以就最終退出「預先批核還息不還本」計劃作好準備，並同時確保暫時面對困難的客戶仍然得到適切的信貸支援。

此外，面對不明朗的宏觀經濟環境，金管局於2023年亦會加強監管認可機構的流動性及市場風險管理。

# 業務操作及科技風險

隨着銀行在業務營運中更廣泛應用科技，金管局會致力提升銀行業的運作穩健性及網絡防衛能力。繼5月發出《監管政策手冊》新單元「運作穩健性」後，金管局會與業界保持緊密聯繫，審視認可機構在制定運作穩健性框架方面的進度。同時，金管局將透過跟進認可機構在「網絡防衛評估框架2.0」評估下發現的問題以及檢視認可機構實施穩固三重數據備份的進展，提高銀行業的網絡防衛能力。

隨着數碼化的步伐加快，金管局的其他監管重點包括加強對銀行的第三方服務供應商風險管理的監管，以及提升銀行業的數據管治能力。

# 打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集

在2023年，金管局的工作重點包括更新監管資訊、加強打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集（反洗錢）生態系統各持份者的合作以應對洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集（洗錢）風險，以及進一步推動反洗錢監管科技與合規科技的發展。金管局的《打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集指引》亦會作出修訂，並會就「政治人物」採取與風險相稱的措施發出具體指引，從而促進業界以有效及風險為本的方法落實法例的主要修訂。與此同時，金管局會擴大現有公私營夥伴合作的涵蓋範圍以加強訊息共享，以及支持推出銀行之間的訊息共享平台，藉以加快偵測可疑戶口及防範戶口被濫用，並加強對騙案受害人的保障和協助受害人追討損失。金管局亦會透過「反洗錢合規科技實驗室」及其他反洗錢合規科技項目，進一步集中推動採用合規科技（包括數據分析），並致力發展宏觀分析能力，以配合其數據為本的反洗錢監管工作。透過實施上述各項措施，金管局將能更迅速針對傀儡戶口網絡等系統性洗錢風險採取相應措施，以及靈活應對不斷轉變的威脅。

# 財富管理業務

金管局在2023年會加強有關認可機構在財富管理以及銷售證券、強制性公積金（強積金）與其他投資及保險產品方面的操守的現場審查及非現場監察。2023年的重點將會是「跨境理財通」計劃、數碼分銷及諮詢平台、虛擬資產、環境、社會及管治(ESG)投資產品及長期保險產品。金管局在有關過程中會參考市場最新發展及國際標準的修訂。

金管局亦會與其他監管機構及銀行界緊密聯繫，並按需要就銷售投資、保險及強積金產品的監管標準向認可機構提供指引，其中亦會包括有關提供虛擬資產相關投資服務的指引。就此而言，為促進虛擬資產行業可持續及負責任地發展，金管局會積極參與相關國際組織，並與政府及其他金融監管機構合作，制定全面的虛擬資產監管架構。

隨着「跨境理財通」順利推出，金管局會與業界及相關監管機構聯繫，以優化該計劃。此外，金管局亦會與證券及期貨事務監察委員會（證監會）及業界合作，精簡投資產品銷售程序（包括適用於資深投資者的銷售程序），以及開始根據相關《監管政策手冊》新單元及新營運守則監管認可機構的信託業務。

# 監察金融市場基建

金管局的目標是按照《支付系統及儲值支付工具條例》（《支付條例》）、《金融市場基建的原則》（《基建原則》），以及支付及金融基建委員會發出的各項指引促進其所監察的金融市場基建的安全及效率，按需要參照最新的國際標準評估各項基建。金管局會參與支付及金融基建委員會與國際證監會組織對實施《基建原則》的監察及評估計劃，亦會參與國際標準制定組織的工作，並參照國際慣例或因應市場及科技發展加強本身的監察規定。同時，如有需要，金管局會與有關當局合作，進一步加強合作監察安排。

# 制定政策

金管局會因應國際標準及最佳做法，繼續加強及優化銀行監管架構與政策。

# 在香港實施巴塞爾標準

# 資本標準

金管局會透過實施巴塞爾銀行監管委員會（巴塞爾委員會）近年發布的標準，進一步優化資本框架，當中包括：
- 2017年12月《巴塞爾協定三：危機後改革的最終方案》、2019年1月（2019年2月修訂）《市場風險最低資本規定》，以及2020年7月《信用估值調整風險架構具針對性的修訂》所載的經修訂資本標準 — 上述經修訂資本標準統稱《巴塞爾協定三》最終改革方案，載明信用風險、市場風險、信用估值調整風險及業務操作風險的新監管處理方法，並引入出項下限規定，以及優化槓桿比率框架。經過2022年的多輪業界諮詢後，金管局計劃在2023年就《銀行業（資本）規則》（《資本規則》）的建議修訂進行法定諮詢，以實施上述各項規定及正值中性逆周期緩衝資本。有關修訂預計於同年內提交立法會進行先訂立後審議程序，並不早於2024年1月1日生效，作為最低要求。
- 2022年12月《加密資產風險承擔的審慎處理方法》金管局計劃按照巴塞爾委員會的時間表，在2025年1月1日於本地實施有關標準，並打算於2023年就相關建議諮詢業界。

# 風險承擔限度

金管局於2023年3月就《銀行業（風險承擔限度）規則》的建議修訂諮詢業界。有關建議修訂主要是因應金管局實施上文提及的《巴塞爾協定三》最終改革方案下的經修訂資本標準而提出。諮詢文件亦包括就《資本規則》下有關官方實體集中風險的處理方法所作出的其他相應修訂。經修訂規則的目標實施日期將與落實《巴塞爾協定三》最終改革方案的經修訂《資本規則》中的信用風險部分的實施日期一致（即不早於2024年1月1日）。

# 流動性標準

金管局擬於2023年諮詢業界有關透過《2023年銀行業（流動性）（修訂）規則》（《2023年流動性修訂規則》）對《銀行業（流動性）規則》作出的建議修訂。相關修訂是因應同時期的《資本規則》建議修訂而作出，所以《2023年流動性修訂規則》的目標實施日期將與落實《巴塞爾協定三》最終改革方案的經修訂《資本規則》中的信用風險部分的實施日期一致（即不早於2024年1月1日）。

# 披露標準

《巴塞爾協定三》最終改革方案中與經修訂資本標準相關的新的及經修訂的披露規定，主要載於巴塞爾委員會分別於2018年12月及2021年11月發出的《第三支柱1 披露規定 — 更新框架》及《修訂市場風險披露規定》。巴塞爾委員會亦於2019年6月發出《修訂槓桿比率披露規定》，藉修訂槓桿比率的披露規定處理對潛在「粉飾櫥窗」（指銀行在報告日期前後減少某些交易的交易量，從而人為地提高報告及公開披露的槓桿比率）的關注。為在香港實施上述新的及經修訂的披露規定，金管局亦正擬備《銀行業（披露）規則》（《披露規則》）的相應修訂，以及經修訂後的標準披露模版及表格，並在過程中徵詢業界意見。預計《披露規則》的修訂將於2023年內連同《資本規則》的修訂一併提交立法會進行先訂立後審議程序。

# Key Work Priorities and Future Outlook for 2023

Although Hong Kong's economy showed signs of recovery in early 2023, the external environment remains full of challenges and uncertainties. Recent pressures in the banking sectors of the United States and Europe, including the collapse of several U.S. banks in March 2023, have created ripple effects in global financial markets. Furthermore, the tightening of monetary policies by major central banks is likely to slow down, or even cause a recession, in global economic growth in 2023. On the other hand, geopolitical tensions and the ongoing threat of deglobalization may continue to weigh on global trade and cause volatility in global financial markets. Nevertheless, Hong Kong's financial system, built on years of robust resilience and ample buffers, has sufficient capacity to withstand adverse shocks.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority places great importance on safeguarding monetary and financial stability. Looking ahead, in the face of an uncertain macroeconomic environment, the HKMA will remain vigilant, striving to quickly identify emerging risks and respond flexibly. At the same time, the HKMA will continue to seize opportunities and create policy space to further enhance Hong Kong’s position as a leading international financial center. Faced with a challenging investment environment, the HKMA will continue to invest prudently when managing the Exchange Fund, while maintaining sufficient flexibility to take defensive measures as needed and preserving high liquidity.

# The financial system remains stable and sound.

The global economic outlook remains subject to significant uncertainties. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority will closely monitor the latest developments, remain vigilant, and guard against various potential risks to maintain the stability and soundness of the financial system – a prerequisite for the continued provision of essential financial services and, therefore, the lifeline for Hong Kong’s normal economic operation.

# Remain vigilant about potential risks.

In 2023, uncertainty surrounding the future trajectory of US interest rates and pressures emerging within the banking systems of advanced economies could pose downside risks to the growth prospects of major advanced economies. Furthermore, persistent geopolitical risks may continue to weigh on global trade and cause volatility in global financial markets. However, Hong Kong’s financial system, bolstered by the resilience and buffers built up over the past few years, possesses ample capacity to withstand adverse shocks. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority also has the ability, resources, and determination to maintain the stability of Hong Kong’s currency and financial system.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority will continue to closely monitor risks and vulnerabilities in the local and external environment, and will take appropriate measures as needed to maintain the stability of Hong Kong’s monetary and financial systems. The Authority will also study matters that may affect the Hong Kong economy and assess the potential risks associated with them.

# Maintain the stability of the banking system.

Given the escalating geopolitical tensions and significant interest rate hikes by major central banks to curb inflation, the operating environment for the banking sector is expected to remain challenging in 2023. On the other hand, rapid technological advancements and digitalization present both opportunities and risks for the banking industry. In the face of a rapidly changing financial landscape, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority is committed to ensuring banks have sufficient resilience to withstand shocks through ongoing regulatory efforts. At the same time, the HKMA will continue to strengthen and optimize the banking regulatory framework and policies, referencing international standards and best practices.

# Risk-based regulatory focus

# Credit, Liquidity, and Market Risk

In 2023, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority will continue to closely monitor the asset quality of licensed institutions, with a focus on their loan classification and provisioning practices, as well as their management of borrowers in weaker financial positions. The HKMA will also strengthen its supervisory systems and take proactive measures to ensure the overall credit risk level of the banking system remains manageable.

Meanwhile, the Financial Services and Markets Commission will continue to monitor the operating environment of businesses and maintain close communication with the banking sector and the business community to prepare for the final phase-out of the "pre-approved principal and interest repayment suspension" scheme, while ensuring that customers facing temporary difficulties continue to receive appropriate credit support.

Furthermore, in the face of an uncertain macroeconomic environment, the Financial Supervisory Commission will also strengthen the supervision of liquidity and market risk management of licensed financial institutions in 2023.

# Business Operations and Technology Risks

As banks increasingly adopt technology in their operations, the Financial Supervisory Commission will focus on enhancing the soundness of their operations and network defense capabilities. Following the release of a new section, "Operational Resilience," in the "Regulatory Policy Handbook" in May, the Commission will maintain close contact with the industry to review the progress of licensed institutions in developing operational resilience frameworks. Simultaneously, the Commission will strengthen the banking sector's network defense capabilities by tracking issues identified under the "Network Defense Assessment Framework 2.0" and reviewing the progress of licensed institutions in implementing robust triple data backups.

As digitalization accelerates, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s other regulatory priorities include strengthening oversight of banks’ management of risks associated with third-party service providers, and enhancing the data governance capabilities of the banking sector.

# Combating Money Laundering and the Financing of Terrorism

In 2023, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s key priorities included updating regulatory information, strengthening collaboration among stakeholders in the anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing (AML/CTF) ecosystem to address AML/CTF risks, and further promoting the development of AML regulatory and compliance technology (RegTech). The HKMA’s Guidance on Countering Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing will be revised, and specific guidance will be issued on measures proportionate to the risk for “politically exposed persons” to facilitate the industry’s implementation of the key amendments to the law in an effective and risk-based manner. Concurrently, the HKMA will expand the scope of existing public-private partnerships to enhance information sharing and support the launch of a message-sharing platform among banks, to expedite the detection of suspicious accounts and prevent account misuse, and to strengthen protection for victims of fraud and assist them in recovering losses. The HKMA will also further promote the adoption of RegTech (including data analytics) through the AML RegTech Sandbox and other AML RegTech initiatives, and strive to develop macro-prudential analytical capabilities to support its data-driven AML regulatory work. Through the implementation of these measures, the HKMA will be better positioned to take timely and appropriate actions against systemic money laundering risks such as nominee account networks, and to flexibly respond to evolving threats.

# Wealth Management Services

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority will strengthen its on-site inspections and off-site monitoring of licensed corporations’ conduct in wealth management, and the sale of securities, mandatory provident fund (MPF) schemes, and other investment and insurance products in 2023. Key areas of focus for 2023 will include the “Cross-border Wealth Management Connect” scheme, digital distribution and advisory platforms, virtual assets, environmental, social, and governance (ESG) investment products, and long-term insurance products. The HKMA will refer to the latest market developments and revisions to international standards in this process.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority will also maintain close contact with other regulatory bodies and the banking sector, and will provide guidance to authorized institutions on regulatory standards for the sale of investment, insurance, and occupational retirement scheme products as needed, including guidance on providing virtual asset-related investment services. To this end, to promote the sustainable and responsible development of the virtual asset industry, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority will actively participate in relevant international organizations and collaborate with the government and other financial regulatory bodies to develop a comprehensive virtual asset regulatory framework.

Following the successful launch of the "Cross-Border Wealth Management Connect" scheme, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority will liaise with the industry and relevant regulatory bodies to optimize the plan. Furthermore, the HKMA will collaborate with the Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) and the industry to streamline the sales process for investment products (including the sales process for sophisticated investors), and begin regulating the trust businesses of authorized institutions in accordance with the new modules and operational guidelines in the relevant "Regulatory Policy Manuals."

# Monitoring Financial Market Infrastructure

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s objective is to promote the safety and efficiency of the financial market infrastructures it oversees, in accordance with the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facilities Ordinance (the “Payment Ordinance”), the Principles for Financial Market Infrastructures (the “PFMI”), and various guidance issued by the Payment and Financial Market Infrastructure Committee. It will assess these infrastructures, as needed, by reference to the latest international standards. The HKMA will participate in the Payment and Financial Market Infrastructure Committee and the International Organization of Securities Commissions’ monitoring and assessment plan for the implementation of the PFMI, and will also participate in the work of international standard-setting bodies, strengthening its supervisory regulations by reference to international practices and in response to market and technological developments. Furthermore, where necessary, the HKMA will collaborate with relevant authorities to further strengthen cooperative supervisory arrangements.

# Formulating policies

The Financial Supervisory Agency will continue to strengthen and optimize the banking regulatory framework and policies in line with international standards and best practices.

# Implementing Basel Standards in Hong Kong

# Capital standards

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) will further optimize the capital framework by implementing standards recently released by the Basel Bank for International Settlements (Basel Committee), including:
- Revised capital standards outlined in the Basel III final reforms, specifically the “Basel III: Final Reform of the Post-Crisis Framework” published in December 2017, the “Minimum Capital Requirements for Market Risk” revised in January 2019 (amended in February 2019), and the “Targeted Revisions to the Credit Valuation Adjustment Risk Framework” published in July 2020. These revised capital standards are collectively referred to as the Basel III final reform package, which specifies new regulatory approaches to credit risk, market risk, credit valuation adjustment risk, and operational risk, and introduces an output floor, as well as optimizes the leverage ratio framework. Following multiple rounds of industry consultation in 2022, the HKMA plans to launch a statutory consultation in 2023 on proposed amendments to the “Banking (Capital) Rules” (the “Capital Rules”) to implement the aforementioned provisions and the countercyclical capital buffer. These amendments are expected to be submitted to the Legislative Council for prior scrutiny and will not take effect before January 1, 2024, as a minimum requirement.
- “Prudential Treatment of Crypto-Asset Risk Exposure” published in December 2022. The HKMA plans to implement these standards locally by January 1, 2025, in accordance with the Basel Committee’s timeline, and intends to consult the industry on related proposals in 2023.

# Risk Tolerance Limit

The Financial Supervisory Commission consulted with the industry in March 2023 regarding proposed amendments to the "Regulations on Risk Exposure Limits for the Banking Industry." These proposed amendments primarily respond to the revised capital standards implemented by the Commission as part of the final reform package under the Basel III framework. The consultation document also includes other related amendments to the handling of concentrated credit risk for official entities under the "Capital Rules." The target implementation date for the revised regulations will align with the implementation date of the revised credit risk portion of the "Capital Rules" under the final reform package of Basel III (no earlier than January 1, 2024).

# Liquidity standards

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority proposes to consult the industry regarding suggested amendments to the Banking (Liquidity) Rules via the Banking (Liquidity) (Amendment) Rules 2023 (the “2023 Liquidity Amendment Rules”). These amendments are in response to concurrent suggested amendments to the Capital Rules, and therefore the target implementation date for the 2023 Liquidity Amendment Rules will align with the implementation date of the revised Capital Rules relating to the credit risk component of the Basel III final reform package (i.e., no earlier than January 1, 2024).

# Disclosure Standards

The new and revised disclosure requirements related to revised capital standards in the final reform package of the Basel III framework are primarily outlined in the Basel Committee’s publications, “Pillar 3 Disclosure Requirements – Updated Framework” issued in December 2018 and “Revised Market Risk Disclosure Requirements” issued in November 2021. The Basel Committee also issued “Revised Leverage Ratio Disclosure Requirements” in June 2019 to address concerns regarding potential “window dressing” (referring to the practice of banks reducing the volume of certain transactions around the reporting date to artificially inflate the reported and publicly disclosed leverage ratio). To implement these new and revised disclosure requirements in Hong Kong, the HKMA is also preparing corresponding amendments to the “Banking (Disclosure) Rules” (“Disclosure Rules”), as well as revised standard disclosure templates and forms, and is consulting with the industry throughout the process. It is anticipated that the amendments to the “Disclosure Rules” will be submitted to the Legislative Council for prior consultation and enactment in 2023, together with the amendments to the “Capital Rules.”

# 機構管治

金管局作為香港的中央銀行機構，深明良好的管治對維持及維護公眾對金管局履行其法定職責的信任及信心的重要性，因此一直致力秉持高水平的機構管治。

為實踐良好機構管治的承諾，金管局：
- 建立了一套清晰且具備高問責性的機構管治架構；
- 實施完善穩健的監控措施以管理風險，並確保所有職級員工的行為及其日常運作均符合指定標準；及
- 奉行具透明度及保持開放的政策，與各持份者保持緊密聯繫。

# 金管局與香港特別行政區政府

金管局是香港特別行政區政府（特區政府）架構的一部分，但可以按與公務員不同的聘用條款聘請員工，以吸引具適當經驗與專門知識的人才。金管局總裁及其員工均為公職人員。金管局的日常運作，在金融管理專員所獲賦予或轉授的法定權力範圍內高度自主。

財政司司長負責釐定香港的貨幣政策目標及貨幣體制：財政司司長於2003年6月25日致金融管理專員的函件中，訂明應透過貨幣發行局制度維持貨幣穩定，將港元匯率保持在約7.80港元兌1美元的水平。金融管理專員須自行負責達成貨幣政策目標，包括決定有關的策略、工具及執行方式，並負責維持香港貨幣制度的穩定與健全。

財政司司長在財經事務及庫務局局長的協助下，負責維持香港金融體系穩定與健全，以及保持香港的國際金融中心地位的政策。為推行這些政策，金融管理專員的職責包括：
- 促進銀行體系的整體穩定與有效運作；
- 與其他有關機構與組織合作，發展債務市場；
- 處理與法定紙幣及硬幣的發行及流通有關的事宜；
- 透過發展支付、結算及交收系統，以及在適當情況下負責操作有關系統，促進金融基建的安全與效率；及
- 與其他有關機構與組織合作，促進對香港貨幣及金融體系的信心，並推行適當的發展市場措施，以協助加強香港金融服務的國際競爭力。

外匯基金由財政司司長掌有控制權。金融管理專員須根據財政司司長轉授的權力，就外匯基金的運用及投資管理向財政司司長負責。

# 問責性與透明度

就日常運作及推行政府政策目標所採用的方法，金管局一直保持高度自主，並同時輔以高問責性及透明度。

金管局致力促進貨幣與銀行體系穩定，有效管理官方儲備，發展與監察穩健及多元化的金融基建，從而鞏固香港的國際金融中心地位，推動香港經濟發展。

金管局要有效履行職責，便必須取得社會人士的信任。因此，金管局以嚴謹的態度，履行向公眾解釋其政策及工作的責任，並盡力處理備受社會關注而涉及金管局職責範圍的事項。尤其，金管局透過傳統及社交媒體適時澄清有關金管局政策的失實資訊及謠言。

金融管理專員由財政司司長委任，因此金管局透過財政司司長向公眾負責；而由於金管局的職權由立法會通過的法律制訂，因此金管局亦透過立法會向公眾負責。金管局亦明白本身肩負更廣泛的責任，就是促進公眾對金管局角色及目標的認識，並密切留意社會人士所關注的事項。金管局在執行日常工作及與社會保持廣泛聯繫時，堅守盡力提高透明度及保持開放的政策。這項政策有兩大目標：
- 在顧及市場敏感性、商業秘密及機密資料披露的法定限制下，盡量使金融界及公眾充分了解金管局的工作；及
- 確保金管局掌握社會脈搏，並對公眾意見作出適當回應。

金管局在透明度方面致力達致國際最高標準，與傳媒保持廣泛聯繫之餘，亦出版各種中英文期刊及專題刊物。金管局的雙語網站(www.hkma.gov.hk)除有專門環節列載經濟研究、統計資料、監管資源、消費者資訊及其他課題外，還載有大量金管局出版的刊物、新聞稿、演辭及簡報會資料文件。此外，金管局又利用社交媒體平台，以能在數碼時代中更有效與公眾溝通。金管局辦事處設有資訊中心，分為圖書館及展覽館兩部分，每星期開放6日予公眾參觀及使用。有關金管局與公眾溝通及聯繫的工作，詳見「機構職能」一章（第157至162頁）。

金管局公布外匯基金及貨幣發行局帳目資料的次數，一直逐步增加，內容亦越趨詳細。金管局於1999年開始參與國際貨幣基金組織的中央銀行「數據公布特殊標準」計劃。金管局亦公布外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下貨幣發行委員會的會議紀錄，以及貨幣發行局制度運作報告。自1996年起，金管局網站載有銀行業監管政策及指引。

金管局與立法會的關係對提高問責性及透明度非常重要。金管局總裁承諾每年3次向立法會財經事務委員會簡報金管局各項工作及政策，並回答有關查詢。此外，金管局代表不時出席立法會事務委員會及小組委員會會議，闡釋及商討特別事項，以及協助議員審閱條例草案。

# 監控措施

金管局採用穩健有效的內部及外部監控機制，確保秉持高水平的員工操守、審慎的風險管理，以及適當的制衡。內部及外部審計職能就監控機制是否足夠及具成效提供獨立評估。

# 行為守則

《行為守則》就員工的道德與法律責任提供指引，確保所有職級員工的行為均符合指定標準。

# 運作監控

風險管理亦在機構層面進行。由金管局總裁擔任主席的風險委員會，是機構風險管理架構的基石之一。

風險委員會審視和商討各部門所識別的潛在及新生風險，以及相關監控措施和緩解策略是否充足，並由該會定出適當的跟進行動。

金管局內部審核處獨立評估不同部門的管治程序、風險管理及監控措施是否足夠及具成效，並提出改善建議。

# Institutional governance

As the de facto central banking institution of Hong Kong, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority fully understands the importance of good governance in maintaining and safeguarding public trust and confidence in its fulfillment of statutory duties, and has therefore consistently strived to uphold the highest standards of institutional governance.

To uphold its commitment to sound corporate governance, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority:
- Has established a clear and highly accountable governance framework;
- Implements robust monitoring measures to manage risk and ensure that the conduct and daily operations of all staff adhere to established standards; and
- Adopts transparent and open policies, maintaining close engagement with stakeholders.

# The Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is a part of the Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (HKSAR), but it employs staff under terms of service different from those of civil servants, in order to attract talent with the appropriate experience and specialized knowledge. The Chief Executive of the HKMA and its staff are public officers. The HKMA enjoys a high degree of autonomy in its day-to-day operations within the scope of statutory powers delegated or assigned to the Financial Services and the Treasury Bureau.

The Financial Secretary is responsible for determining Hong Kong’s monetary policy objectives and monetary system. In a letter to the Financial Secretary on June 25, 2003, the Financial Management Specialist stipulated that monetary stability should be maintained through a currency issuance bureau system, keeping the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate at approximately HK$7.80 per US dollar. The Financial Management Specialist is independently responsible for achieving the monetary policy objectives, including deciding on the relevant strategies, tools, and implementation methods, and for maintaining the stability and soundness of Hong Kong’s monetary system.

The Financial Secretary, with the assistance of the Secretary for the Treasury, is responsible for policies aimed at maintaining the stability and soundness of Hong Kong's financial system and preserving its status as an international financial center. To implement these policies, the responsibilities of the Financial Services and the Treasury Bureau include:
- Promoting the overall stability and effective operation of the banking system;
- Collaborating with other relevant institutions and organizations to develop the debt market;
- Handling matters relating to the issuance and circulation of legal tender banknotes and coins;
- Promoting the safety and efficiency of financial infrastructure through the development of payment, clearing, and settlement systems, and, where appropriate, operating those systems; and
- Collaborating with other relevant institutions and organizations to foster confidence in Hong Kong's currency and financial system, and implementing appropriate market development measures to help strengthen the international competitiveness of Hong Kong's financial services.

The Exchange Fund is under the control of the Financial Secretary. The Financial Management Specialist is responsible to the Financial Secretary for the management and investment of the Exchange Fund, acting under the authority delegated by the Financial Secretary.

# Accountability and Transparency

The Financial Services and Markets Commission has consistently maintained a high degree of autonomy in its day-to-day operations and in the methods it employs to achieve government policy objectives, while also ensuring accountability and transparency.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is committed to promoting the stability of the monetary and banking systems, effectively managing official reserves, developing and supervising a sound and diversified financial infrastructure, thereby consolidating Hong Kong’s status as an international financial center and driving economic development in Hong Kong.

To effectively fulfill its responsibilities, the Financial Supervisory Commission must earn the public’s trust. Therefore, the Commission diligently explains its policies and work to the public and makes every effort to address issues of public concern that fall within its purview. In particular, the Commission clarifies inaccurate information and rumors regarding its policies through traditional and social media as needed.

The Financial Management Specialist is appointed by the Financial Secretary and therefore the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is accountable to the public through the Financial Secretary; and because the HKMA’s authority is established by laws passed by the Legislative Council, the HKMA is also accountable to the public through the Legislative Council. The HKMA also understands that it bears a broader responsibility, namely to promote public understanding of the HKMA’s role and objectives, and to closely monitor matters of concern to the community. In carrying out its daily work and maintaining extensive engagement with society, the HKMA is committed to maximizing transparency and maintaining an open policy. This policy has two main objectives:
- To ensure that the financial sector and the public have as much understanding as possible of the HKMA’s work, while respecting statutory limitations on the disclosure of market sensitivity, commercial secrets, and confidential information; and
- To ensure that the HKMA stays attuned to public sentiment and responds appropriately to public opinion.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is committed to achieving the highest international standards in transparency. In addition to maintaining extensive communication with the media, it also publishes various Chinese and English journals and special publications. The HKMA’s bilingual website (www.hkma.gov.hk) features dedicated sections on economic research, statistical data, regulatory resources, consumer information, and other topics, as well as a wealth of HKMA publications, press releases, speeches, and presentation materials. Furthermore, the HKMA utilizes social media platforms to communicate more effectively with the public in the digital age. The HKMA’s office houses an Information Centre, comprising a library and an exhibition hall, which is open to the public six days a week. Details on the HKMA’s efforts to communicate and engage with the public can be found in the chapter “Institutional Functions” (pages 157 to 162).

The number of times the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) publishes data on the Exchange Fund and Currency Board accounts has steadily increased, and the content has become more detailed. The HKMA began participating in the International Monetary Fund’s Special Data Dissemination Standard (SDDS) for central banks in 1999. The HKMA also publishes minutes of meetings of the Currency Board Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, as well as reports on the operation of the Currency Board system. Since 1996, the HKMA website has featured banking sector supervisory policies and guidelines.

The relationship between the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) and the Legislative Council is crucial for enhancing accountability and transparency. The HKMA Chief Executive has pledged to brief the Legislative Council’s House Committee on Financial Affairs three times a year on the HKMA’s various work and policies, and to answer related inquiries. Furthermore, HKMA representatives regularly attend meetings of the House Committee and various select committees to explain and discuss specific matters, and to assist legislators in reviewing draft legislation.

# Surveillance Measures

The Financial Supervisory Commission employs robust and effective internal and external monitoring mechanisms to ensure a high standard of employee integrity, prudent risk management, and appropriate checks and balances. Internal and external audit functions provide independent assessments of the adequacy and effectiveness of these monitoring mechanisms.

# Code of Conduct

The Code of Conduct provides guidance on employees’ ethical and legal responsibilities, ensuring that the conduct of all employees at every level aligns with established standards.

# Internal monitoring

# Operation Monitoring

As the first line of defense in risk management, all departments and branches are responsible for assessing the risks within their workflows and establishing appropriate monitoring measures to ensure the smooth and stable operation of the Financial Supervisory Agency.

# Enterprise Risk Management

Risk management is also carried out at the institutional level. The Risk Committee, chaired by the Governor of the Financial Supervisory Agency, is one of the cornerstones of the institution’s risk management framework.

The Risk Committee reviews and discusses potential and emerging risks identified by various departments, as well as whether the related monitoring measures and mitigation strategies are adequate, and determines appropriate follow-up actions.

# Internal Audit

The Financial Services and Markets Authority’s Internal Audit Division independently assesses whether the governance procedures, risk management, and monitoring measures of various departments are adequate and effective, and submits improvement recommendations.

# External Audit

According to Section 7 of the Exchange Fund Bill, the financial statements of the Exchange Fund are audited by the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Government Audit Commission. The Audit Commission does not charge a fee for this service. The audited Exchange Fund financial statements are published in the Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s Annual Report.

# 經濟及金融環境

面對第五波新冠病毒疫情、金融狀況收緊及充滿挑戰的外圍環境，香港經濟在2022年顯著收縮。勞工市場持續一段時間轉差，其後逐步改善，而通脹則維持溫和。資產市場亦有所受壓。受惠於內地與香港全面通關，預計2023年香港經濟增長將由低位復甦。

# 經濟回顧

# 實體經濟活動

受本地及外圍環境各項不利因素拖累，香港經濟在2022年收縮3.5%（表1及圖1）。本地方面，由於香港爆發第五波新冠病毒疫情，私人消費在第1季急跌，其後受惠於社交距離措施逐步放寬及政府消費券計劃的刺激，私人消費再度錄得按季增長。在營商氣氛疲弱及金融狀況收緊下，整體投資支出較2021年顯著下跌。對外方面，隨着外部需求轉弱，加上內地與香港之間的跨境陸路貨運受阻，香港貨物出口下挫。服務輸出依然大致疲弱，部分反映訪港旅遊活動低迷，但其後隨着政府於9月下旬撤銷抵港強制檢疫要求，情況於第4季稍為改善。

圖1 組成部分對實質本地生產總值增長的貢獻

# 通脹

本地通脹壓力於2022年稍升，但仍屬溫和。具體而言，按年基本通脹率逐步上升至12月2%的溫和水平，其中外圍能源及食品價格高企的影響部分被溫和的本地成本壓力所抵銷，尤其是偏軟的房屋租金（圖2）。此外，在經濟活動疲弱下，名義工資增長及商業樓宇租金持續偏軟，亦有助遏抑通脹。2022年全年合計，基本及整體通脹率分別為1.7%及1.9%。

# 勞工市場

疫情下勞工市場狀況在2022年初急速惡化，但隨後持續改善。失業率在4月升至5.4%的高位後，於12月顯著回落至3.5%（圖3），當中大多數行業的失業率均有所下降。總就業人數（圖3）及私營機構職位空缺回升，反映整體勞工需求逐步回復，惟總就業人數仍低於疫情前水平。名義工資和勞工收入的按年升幅亦略為加快。另一方面，與去年同期比較，勞動人口於12月略為減少1.5%，部分原因是勞動人口參與率輕微下跌。

# 股市

本港股市在2022年出現大幅波動。承接2021年的下行趨勢，恒生指數加速下跌，在2022年10月31日收報14,687點，是自2009年以來的最低水平（圖4）。股市顯著調整，最初是由市場對本地新冠病毒疫情、美國加息及俄烏局勢的憂慮加劇所觸發，其後由於環球金融狀況收緊及內地新冠病毒疫情導致環球經濟前景轉差，令股市調整幅度進一步擴大。股市在年內最後兩個月重拾一些上升動力，部分受到內地優化防疫抗疫措施所支持。恒生指數於年底收報19,781點，較2021年底顯著下跌15.5%，連續第三年下挫。

# 物業市場

在金融狀況收緊及經濟活動疲弱下，住宅物業市場亦有所受壓。樓價於2022年回落15%（圖4），成交量也大幅縮減39%至45,050宗，創下有紀錄以來的新低。儘管樓價下跌，置業負擔能力仍然偏緊。實際按揭利率於年內由約1.6厘上升至3.375至3.625厘，增加供樓人士的按揭供款負擔。非住宅物業市場亦進一步回軟。在空置率高企下，其價格有所回落，租金亦維持偏軟。

# 經濟前景

# 經濟環境

受惠於內地與香港全面通關，預期2023年香港經濟增長將由低位復甦。儘管先進經濟體增長預期放緩將繼續拖累香港貨物出口，但內地經濟復甦及跨境陸路貨運限制撤銷，應能為本港經濟提供支持。內地與香港全面通關亦有望令香港入境旅遊及其他服務輸出顯著受惠，並提振本地營商氣氛及資本開支。私人消費亦將會在勞工市場轉強下進一步改善。政府預測2023年全年實質本地生產總值會顯著增長，介乎3.5至5.5%。然而，香港經濟增長前景仍受眾多風險及不明朗因素所影響，並很大程度上取決於美國聯邦儲備局政策利率走勢、全球增長前景、地緣政治局勢持續緊張以及本地入境旅遊的復甦步伐。

# 通脹及勞工市場

展望未來，預期本地通脹將輕微上升，但在各種因素互相抵銷下應保持溫和。儘管外圍價格應會維持高企，但由於部分主要經濟體的經濟活動轉弱及商品價格上行壓力緩和，外圍價格的上升動力或會進一步減弱。同樣地，隨着本地經濟復甦及勞工市場改善，本地成本壓力或會輕微上升，但房屋租金偏軟應繼續在一定程度上抵銷其影響。政府預測2023年全年合計的整體及基本通脹率分別為2.9%及2.5%。另一方面，勞工市場狀況有望隨着本地經濟活動復常而進一步改善。

# 銀行體系表現

香港銀行體系在2022年面對充滿挑戰的宏觀經濟環境，包括年初爆發第五波新冠病毒疫情、地緣政治局勢升溫，以及全球各大央行大幅度加息應對通脹上升等。面對各項挑戰，香港銀行應付裕如，資本及流動性狀況繼續保持充裕。年內銀行體系面對的信貸風險增加，但整體資產質素維持於健康水平。與此同時，利率上升促使銀行淨利息收入增加，但其正面影響因呆壞帳準備金增加及費用與佣金收入減少而被局部抵銷。整體而言，零售銀行盈利較2021年改善。

# 資產質素

銀行體系的特定分類貸款比率由2021年底的0.89%上升至2022年底的1.38%，逾期及經重組貸款比率於同期由0.56%升至0.85%（圖5）。中國內地相關貸款的特定分類貸款比率於2022年底為2.21%，亦較2021年底的0.89%上升。特定分類貸款比率上升，主要是由於部分內地房地產發展商的貸款評級被下調。儘管如此，銀行撥備充足，截至2022年底，銀行信貸撥備覆蓋率（即信貸撥備和特定分類貸款比率）約維持於80%。若將抵押品變現價值從呆壞帳餘額中扣除，銀行信貸撥備覆蓋率約140%。另一方面，2022年底住宅按揭貸款及信用卡貸款的拖欠比率仍然處於低位，分別為0.06%及0.23%（圖6）。

# 盈利走勢

銀行體系在2022年繼續錄得盈利。年內零售銀行的整體除稅前經營溢利上升19.0%（圖7）。盈利改善是受惠於淨利息收入（+34%）及外匯與衍生工具收入增加（+72%），但部分升幅被呆壞帳準備金增加（+151%）及費用與佣金收入減少（–19%）所抵銷。在加息環境下，淨息差由上一年的0.98%擴闊至2022年的1.31%（圖8）。年內市場波動增加，亦令銀行來自外匯及衍生工具業務的收入增加。呆壞帳準備金增加是由於須為新的特定分類貸款預留特殊準備金，而在金融市場表現疲弱下，費用及佣金收入減少。零售銀行成本與收入比率由2021年的54.7%，降至2022年的48.0%（圖9）。

# 資產負債表走勢

2022年銀行體系資產負債表擴大2.5%。資產上升是由於外匯及衍生工具持倉按市價計值增加。面對外圍不明朗因素及利率趨升，年內貸款需求減弱。相比2021年錄得3.8%的增幅，2022年貸款總額減少3.0%。其中在香港境外使用的貸款減少10.2%，貿易融資減少13.5%，在香港使用的貸款則稍增0.9%。中國內地相關貸款繼2021年增長3.7%後，於2022年減少4.4%。

在資產負債表的負債方面，銀行體系存款繼續錄得溫和增長。存款總額於2022年增加1.7%，相比2021年的增幅為4.6%。由於貸款總額減少而存款總額增加，整體貸存比率由2021年底的71.8%稍降至2022年底的68.5%（圖10）。

# 資本充足水平

銀行在2022年的資本狀況維持充裕。2022年底本地註冊認可機構的綜合總資本比率為20.1%，相比上一年為20.2%；一級資本比率為18.1%（圖11）。兩者均遠高於相關國際最低要求。《巴塞爾協定三》槓桿比率於2022年底為7.9%（圖12）。

# 流動性狀況

銀行體系的流動性狀況繼續維持穩健，成為在宏觀經濟環境不明朗因素加劇下的重要支柱。第1類機構的季度平均流動性覆蓋比率在2022年第4季為162.3%，第2類機構的季度平均流動性維持比率為63.2%（圖13）。銀行體系的主要資金來源仍然是客戶存款。於2022年底，第1類機構的穩定資金淨額比率及第2A類機構的核心資金比率分別為137.7%及155.7%（圖14）。以上所有4個比率均遠高於法定最低要求。

# Economic and Financial Environment

Faced with the fifth wave of the COVID-19 pandemic, tightening financial conditions, and a challenging external environment, Hong Kong's economy contracted significantly in 2022. The labor market initially deteriorated for a period before gradually improving, while inflation remained moderate. Asset markets also experienced pressure. Benefiting from the full resumption of travel between mainland China and Hong Kong, Hong Kong's economy is expected to recover from a low base in 2023.

# Economic Review

# Real-world economic activities

Hong Kong’s economy contracted by 3.5% in 2022, weighed down by various unfavorable factors both locally and externally (Table 1 and Figure 1). Locally, private consumption plummeted in the first quarter due to the outbreak of the fifth wave of the COVID-19 pandemic in Hong Kong. It subsequently rebounded with quarter-on-quarter growth, benefiting from the gradual easing of social distancing measures and the government’s consumption voucher scheme. Overall investment spending declined significantly compared to 2021, amid a weak business climate and tightening financial conditions. Externally, merchandise exports from Hong Kong decreased as external demand weakened and cross-border land freight between mainland China and Hong Kong was disrupted. Service exports remained generally sluggish, partly reflecting the decline in inbound tourism, but improved somewhat in the fourth quarter following the government’s removal of mandatory quarantine requirements for inbound travelers in late September.

# Inflation

Local inflationary pressures rose slightly in 2022 but remained mild. Specifically, the year-on-year underlying inflation rate gradually increased to a modest level of 2% in December, where the impact of high external energy and food prices was partially offset by moderate local cost pressures, particularly soft residential rents (Figure 2). Furthermore, weak economic activity, along with subdued nominal wage growth and commercial rental rates, also helped to contain inflation. For the entire year of 2022, the basic and overall inflation rates were 1.7% and 1.9%, respectively.

# Labor market

The labor market deteriorated rapidly at the beginning of 2022 due to the pandemic, but subsequently improved steadily. The unemployment rate rose to a high of 5.4% in April before falling significantly to 3.5% in December (Figure 3), with unemployment rates declining in most industries. Total employment (Figure 3) and private sector job vacancies rebounded, reflecting a gradual recovery in overall labor demand, although total employment remains below pre-pandemic levels. Nominal wages and labor income growth also accelerated slightly year-on-year. On the other hand, the labor force decreased slightly by 1.5% in December compared to the same period last year, partly due to a slight decrease in labor force participation rate.

# Stock Market

Hong Kong's stock market experienced significant volatility in 2022. Continuing the downward trend from 2021, the Hang Seng Index accelerated its decline, closing at 14,687 points on October 31, 2022 – the lowest level since 2009 (Figure 4). The market underwent a substantial correction, initially triggered by concerns over local COVID-19 outbreaks, US interest rate hikes, and the Russia-Ukraine situation. Subsequently, tightening global financial conditions and the COVID-19 situation in mainland China, which led to a deterioration in the global economic outlook, further widened the market's correction. The stock market regained some upward momentum in the final two months of the year, partly supported by mainland China's optimization of its pandemic prevention and control measures. The Hang Seng Index closed the year at 19,781 points, a significant 15.5% decrease from the end of 2021, marking the third consecutive year of decline.

# Property Market

Amidst tightening financial conditions and a weakening economy, the residential property market has also come under pressure. Property prices fell by 15% in 2022 (Figure 4), and transaction volumes also decreased significantly by 39% to 45,050, reaching a new low on record. Despite the decline in prices, affordability remains relatively tight. Actual mortgage interest rates rose from approximately 1.6% to 3.375% to 3.625% during the year, increasing the mortgage repayment burden for homeowners. The non-residential property market has also softened further. With high vacancy rates, prices have fallen somewhat, and rents remain subdued.
